ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about the procedures and cases that surround the foundations of the American legal system, with a special focus on Connecticut specifically at times. We discussed ethical issues regarding the judicial system as well.

I learned a lot about the United States legal system, the courts, policies and procedures, etc. Professor Goodrow always framed these concepts around broader ethical concepts, which made the course very intriguing.
Knowledge about court precedent and policies in the criminal justice system, from Miranda warnings to the death penalty.

I learned about miscarriages of justice, and the ethics (and DEEPLY unethical practices) of prosecutors, lawyers, police officers, and judges that deeply impact the legal system and delivery of justice. We also learned a ton from KG's wealth of personal legal experience.
An excellent survey course into the world of law. I learned so much about right to privacy, speech, jurisprudence, and the criminal justice system more broadly.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: Super discussion-based, high level of engagement, organized super well
weaknesses: none that I can think of
The course has a lot of strengths! I didnt have any issues with it. I thought the fact that Professor Goodrow gave a short intro to each of the classes was really helpful overview.

This course has very interesting and salient content, and it is useful knowledge for anyone interested in reading about legal issues or going to law school. However, there isn't a lot of structure and the class conversations can wander all over the place -- kind of a strength and a weakness.

Strengths: KG. An incredible professor. One of the best I've had. Could not recommend her more highly. This class was super interesting with such great stories and concepts.
Weaknesses: Not many I can think of. I've had a good time in the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES!! Professor Goodrow is the coolest and kindest person ever -- she runs an incredibly discussion and student-based class. This was probably one of my favorite Yale courses ever.
Yes!!! KG is fantastic and the course material is super interesting. Would recommend to anyone interested in the US courts.

Yes! If you are interested in the criminal justice system and its complexities, this is a great class for you. KG brings a lot of interesting experience and unique stories from her time on the bench and in the Connecticut Innocence Project, so it's really nice to hear about her life and work.

100%!! If you get into this class and you're interested in the legal system, TAKE THIS CLASS! KG will give you a firsthand experience in how the legal system fails folks with a mixture of SCOTUS cases, personal experience, and other research. Super interesting discussions and class.

Definitely! KG is a wonderful professor who engages with her students wholeheartedly. (Sometimes wish she gave more feedback). It was an excellent introduction into the problems facing the world and the criminal justice system.
